<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 378, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 168, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 211, 422, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 902, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 177, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 259, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 221, 433]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 602]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 904, 840]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 756, 88]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the internal diameter \(d\) of a boiling tube. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 103, 842, 119]]<|/det|> You are provided with an empty boiling tube held vertically in the clamp of a retort stand. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 134, 530, 150]]<|/det|> The apparatus is assembled as shown in Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 161, 716, 408]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 425, 532, 441]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 456, 828, 472]]<|/det|>
Add water from the beaker to the measuring cylinder up to the \(100cm^{3}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 486, 184, 502]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 486, 918, 518]]<|/det|>
Add water from the measuring cylinder to the boiling tube until the boiling tube is approximately one-sixth full.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 533, 184, 550]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 533, 920, 565]]<|/det|>

<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 918, 105]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(G\) of your line. Show all working and indicate on the graph the values you use.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 180, 920, 197]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 211, 918, 228]]<|/det|>
The internal diameter \(d\) of a cylinder is given by the equation \(d=k \sqrt{G}\), where \(k=1.13 \text{ cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 453, 258]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(d\) for the boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 324, 920, 340]]<|/det|>
<form>d =  .................................................... cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 354, 184, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 354, 796, 370]]<|/det|>
Suggest one reason why your calculated value for \(d\) is only approximate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 444, 136, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 918, 476]]<|/det|>
It is important to avoid line-of-sight (parallax) errors when reading the scale of the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 490, 191, 506]]<|/det|>
<label>Describe how such errors are avoided. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 722, 920, 738]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 706, 88]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate a light-dependent resistor (LDR).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
You are provided with a series circuit consisting of a power supply, a switch, a \(470 \Omega\) resistor and an LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 150, 136, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 150, 918, 182]]<|/det|>
Draw a circuit diagram of the circuit that has been set up for you. Choose symbols from the list in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 194, 795, 345]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 362, 532, 378]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 616, 916, 632]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 648, 136, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 648, 184, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 648, 377, 664]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 666, 620, 682]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Connect the voltmeter between points X and Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 695, 475, 711]]<|/det|>
Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{XY}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[535, 725, 885, 741]]<|/det|>
\(V_{XY} =\) .................................................... V [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 755, 184, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 755, 622, 771]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Connect the voltmeter between points Y and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 785, 477, 801]]<|/det|>
Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{YZ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[535, 815, 885, 831]]<|/det|>
\(V_{YZ} =\) .................................................... V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 846, 375, 862]]<|/det|>
\(\cdot\) Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 846, 916, 862]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 32, 415, 70]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 73, 136, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 73, 184, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 678, 89]]<|/det|>
The current \(I\) in the circuit is calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 93, 535, 124]]<|/det|>
\[
I=\frac{V_{XY}}{R},
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 136, 340, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(R=470 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 166, 697, 182]]<|/det|>
Use your voltmeter reading in (b)(i) to calculate the current \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[557, 281, 885, 297]]<|/det|>
<form>I = ................................................................. A [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 315, 184, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 315, 680, 331]]<|/det|>
The resistance of the LDR is calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[459, 335, 538, 365]]<|/det|>
\[
R=\frac{V_{YZ}}{I} .
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 377, 828, 393]]<|/det|>
Use your voltmeter reading in (b)(ii) to calculate the resistance \(R\) of the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 491, 885, 507]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... $\Omega$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 525, 136, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 525, 572, 541]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter from points Y and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 542, 543, 558]]<|/det|>
Place the piece of card on top of the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 572, 483, 588]]<|/det|>
Repeat the measurements made in (b).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[533, 615, 885, 635]]<|/det|>
\[
V_{XY} = ............................................................. V
\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[533, 648, 885, 667]]<|/det|>
\[
V_{YZ} = ............................................................. V
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 663, 916, 679]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 693, 136, 709]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 693, 718, 709]]<|/det|>
Ensure that the voltmeter is connected between points Y and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 711, 345, 727]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 729, 644, 745]]<|/det|>
Hold the card horizontally about 50 cm above the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 746, 771, 762]]<|/det|>
Slowly move the card towards the LDR until it rests on top of the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 763, 690, 779]]<|/det|>
Observe the reading on the voltmeter as you move the card.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 793, 390, 809]]<|/det|>
<pre>Describe your observations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 885, 916, 901]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 32, 415, 64]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 72, 136, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 750, 87]]<|/det|>
When the LDR is covered by the card, the current in the circuit changes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 918, 134]]<|/det|>
Use your results in (b) and (d) to state how this change in current affects the total potential difference \((V_{XY} + V_{YZ})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 258, 136, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 258, 917, 290]]<|/det|>
Compare your value for the potential difference \(V_{YZ}\) across the LDR in bright light in (b) with the value for the potential difference \(V_{YZ}\) across the LDR in the dark in (d).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 306, 917, 338]]<|/det|>
Suggest what causes the change in the readings as the intensity of the light reaching the LDR decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 414, 918, 430]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 761, 88]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the image formed by a converging lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 103, 260, 119]]<|/det|>
Refer to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[167, 130, 834, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 342, 532, 358]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 372, 136, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 372, 184, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 372, 398, 388]]<|/det|>
Switch on the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 390, 918, 419]]<|/det|>
Place the screen a distance \(D=80.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) from the illuminated object (the triangular hole in the card).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 421, 605, 437]]<|/det|>
Place the lens close to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 438, 918, 467]]<|/det|>
Move the lens away from the illuminated object until a magnified, sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 468, 918, 497]]<|/det|>
Do not move the illuminated object, the lens or the screen after this image position is found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 511, 918, 544]]<|/det|>
Measure, to the nearest 0.1 cm, the object distance \(x_{1}\) from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[548, 555, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{1} =  ........................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 555, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 589, 184, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 585, 918, 618]]<|/det|>
Continue to move the lens away from the illuminated object until a diminished, sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 635, 918, 667]]<|/det|>
Measure, to the nearest 0.1 cm, the object distance \(y_{1}\) from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[550, 678, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
<form>y_{1} =  ........................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 678, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 712, 184, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 712, 464, 728]]<|/det|>
Calculate the value \(d=(y_{1}-x_{1})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 775, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
<form>d =  ........................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 775, 920, 791]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 32, 415, 64]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 136, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 666, 88]]<|/det|>
The focal length \(f\) of the lens can be found using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 93, 558, 127]]<|/det|>
\[
f=\frac{(D^{2}-d^{2})}{4D} .
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Use the value of \(D\) from (a)(i) and \(d\) from (a)(iii) to calculate a value \(f_{1}\) for the focal length of the lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 183, 809, 199]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 277, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
<form>f<sub>1</sub> = .................................................... $cm$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 308, 136, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 308, 184, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 308, 918, 340]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure in (a)(i), (a)(ii) and (a)(iii) for an illuminated object to screen distance \(D=100.0 \mathrm{~cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 353, 485, 369]]<|/det|>
Record your values of \(x_{2}, y_{2}\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[548, 386, 920, 402]]<|/det|>
<form>x<sub>2</sub> = ........................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[548, 417, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
<form>y<sub>2</sub> = ........................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 447, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ........................................................ $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 467, 916, 483]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 495, 184, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 495, 918, 527]]<|/det|>
Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens using the equation in (b) and your values in (c)(i).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 616, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
<form>f<sub>2</sub> = ........................................................ $cm$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 646, 136, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 646, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
Two quantities can be considered to be equal within the limits of experimental accuracy if their values are within \(10 \%\) of each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 837, 707]]<|/det|>
State whether your values of \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) from (b) and (c)(ii) can be considered equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 722, 502, 738]]<|/det|>
Support your statement with a calculation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 877, 920, 893]]<|/det|>
statement ...................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 899, 916, 915]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 945, 184, 957]]<|/det|>
<pre>© UCLES 2025

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 918, 105]]<|/det|>
State one technique you use when doing the experiment to ensure that the image on the screen is focused as clearly as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 181, 876, 197]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 628, 227]]<|/det|>
This experiment is usually done in a darkened room.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 746, 258]]<|/det|>
Explain how this makes it easier to see when the image is in focus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[835, 334, 920, 350]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 773, 88]]<|/det|>
Hot water is poured into a glass beaker and allowed to cool down for 5 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the rate of cooling of the hot water depends upon the initial temperature of the hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 150, 688, 166]]<|/det|>
The rate of cooling of the water can be calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 171, 680, 205]]<|/det|>
\[
\text { rate of cooling }=\frac{\text { decrease in temperature }}{\text { time taken }} .
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 212, 304, 228]]<|/det|>
You are provided with:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 243, 340, 258]]<|/det|>
· a supply of cold water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 260, 280, 272]]<|/det|>
· an electric kettle

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 275, 350, 289]]<|/det|>
· a \(250cm^{3}\) glass beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 291, 335, 304]]<|/det|>
· a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 321, 565, 337]]<|/det|>
You may use any other common laboratory apparatus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 352, 485, 368]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 382, 293, 398]]<|/det|>
In your plan, include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 413, 392, 429]]<|/det|>
· any other apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 430, 918, 460]]<|/det|>
· a brief description of the method, including what you will measure and how you will make sure your measurements are accurate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 462, 392, 474]]<|/det|>
· the variables you will control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 477, 918, 505]]<|/det|>
· a results table to record your measurements (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 508, 615, 524]]<|/det|>
· how you will process your results to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 539, 418, 555]]<|/det|>
You may include a labelled diagram.
